Knotweed treated in rear garden and outside along fenceline. Knotweed has been cut behind the neighbouring fence in car park area. Client has been advised and is arranging access to ascertain level of any problem. Spoke with neighbour who has been treating JK for the last forty years. Knotweed growing along garden border four knee height plants by brick wall (subjects) leaflet given to her and advised not to cut stems in car park area by wooden fence. other_values: Excavation by hand of Japanese knotweed rhizome

e77c.caption: Small crown of knotweed visible next to cable

Rhizome removed and no deeper rhizome visible

form_values.2d29:
Excavation of Japanese knotweed from one small stand at the subject property was undertaken in order to allow some light landscaping work to proceed in the impacted area. Previously at this location, very stunted knotweed stems had been growing on a nearly annual basis.
Our client informed PBA of their intention to remove old, decaying sleepers that formed a border edge, and replace them with new, and instructed PBA for supervision of the removal of the sleepers and to conduct a hand excavation of the identified knotweed.
The work was undertaken on 27 October 2023. Previously rainy weather had cleared by the time the work was started.
After a briefing with the landscaping contractor, the sleepers were removed along with a small number of thin branches of a shrub, to improve access for the excavation. Visible rhizome was chased out by digging soil from around it and following it downwards. Some brick rubble was encountered which had deflected the path of the rhizome in places although generally there was little lateral travel. At a depth of approximately 600 mm the knotweed rhizome was observed to have decayed and thinned. No viable rhizome was seen below this depth. One small shoot was observed on the removed rhizome.
Waste soil was checked through and all rhizome fragments were removed. The soil arisings were returned to the dug hole and compacted. Waste rhizome was bagged and removed from the site for later disposal by PBA.
